review.title: Homomorphisms between fuzzy information systems revisited
review.abstract: Recently, Wang et al. discussed the properties of fuzzy information systems under homomorphisms in the paper [C. Wang, D. Chen, L. Zhu, Homomorphisms between fuzzy information systems, Applied Mathematics Letters 22 (2009) 1045-1050], where homomorphisms are based upon the concepts of consistent functions and fuzzy relation mappings. In this paper, we classify consistent functions as predecessor-consistent and successor-consistent, and then proceed to present more properties of consistent functions. In addition, we improve some characterizations of fuzzy relation mappings provided by Wang et al.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Information systems [5, 8], also known as knowledge representation systems, are a formalism for the representation of knowledge about some objects related to attributes (e.g. color) and values of attributes (e.g. green). In recent decades, the concept of information systems has received considerable attention, including some successful applications in information processing, decision-making and control (see, for example, [1, 7, 10, 11, 16, 18, 20]. In order to study transformations of information systems while maintaining their basic functions, a mathematical tool, homomorphism, has been introduced and studied in the literature [2, 6, 14, 15, 19, 21]. More recently, Wang et al. have studied the properties of information systems under homomorphisms in [12, 13]. Specifically, they showed that attribute reductions in the original fuzzy information system and homorphic images are equivalent.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have presented preceding and succession consistent functions in terms of a blurred relationship, which together amount to the notion of consistent functions in the sense of [12]. Some properties of preceding and succession consistent functions have been studied. Based on the classification of consistent functions, we have significantly improved some of the characterizations of blurred relation mappings presented in [12]. The results obtained in this paper may help us establish a homomorphism between two blurred information systems and further compare their properties.
